Main Page | Namespace List | Class Hierarchy | Alphabetical List | Class List | File List | Namespace Members | Class Members | File Members

ScrollingArea::Listener Class Reference

#include <ScrollingArea.h>

Inheritance diagram for ScrollingArea::Listener:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

The base listener interface for scrolling area events.

This listener additionally enables listening to events that are specially transformed for scrolling (e.g. pointer operations).

Note:
The listener concept has been designed for two clients: The main application (e.g. the game) and the skin. Do not create listeners for internal purposes.
Warning:
Listeners are auto-deleting when they are not listening to any component anymore. So you should not hold any references to them.

Definition at line 32 of file ScrollingArea.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

virtual ~Listener (   )  [protected, virtual]
 

Destroys the listener.

Since listeners are managed automatically, you do not need to destroy them by yourself.

Reimplemented from EventTarget::Listener.

Member Function Documentation

void addReference (   )  [inherited]
 

Increases a reference count by one.

void* getModel (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Returns:
The application (or game) defined data.

int getReferences (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the number of open references to this object.

Starts with zero. If no references remain, the object is automatically destroying itself.

Returns:
The number of references.

SkinData* getSkinData (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Returns:
The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

void GlazieryObject::destructor (  void *  model  )  [static, inherited]
 

Destructor function for the setModel() method, when setting a model that is a glaziery object itself.

Parameters:
model The model to be destroyed.
See also:
setModel()

virtual void onAnyKey (  EventTarget *  target,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when any key is pressed on the event target, the target has the inner-most focus, and the event not handled otherwise by the target.

This method is called in addition to another key method, such as onCharacter or onMoveDown. The onAnyKey method is called first.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.

virtual void onBackSpace (  EventTarget *  target  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the BACKSPACE key (backward delete) is pressed on the event target, the target has the inner-most focus, and the event not handled otherwise by the target.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.

virtual void onBackTab (  EventTarget *  target,
bool  secondary
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the back TAB key is pressed on the event target, the target has the inner-most focus, and the event not handled otherwise by the target.

On Windows systems, the back TAB key is SHIFT+TAB. Back tabs step the focus from field to field in backward order.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
secondary Whether the secondary tabbing is used. E.g., on Windows systems, this is done by holding the control key.

virtual void onCharacter (  EventTarget *  target,
char  character,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when a regular character has been entered on the event target, the target has the inner-most focus, and the event not handled otherwise by the target.

This is used for text input fields to enter text.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
character The character pressed, using ISO-8859-1 encoding.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.

virtual void onClick (  EventTarget *  target,
Vector  position,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the target is clicked (usually using the left mouse button).

A click is raised after the mouse has been pressed and released, and no dragging operation has started.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
position The position where the click occurred relative to the upper-left corner of the target.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.
See also:
onPress()

onRelease()

virtual void onContentClick (  Component *  component,
Vector  position,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual]
 

Called when the component is clicked (usually using the left mouse button), called by the scrolling area with content-transformed coordinates.

A click is raised after the mouse has been pressed and released, and no dragging operation has started.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event.
position The position where the click occurred relative to the upper-left corner of the content.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.
See also:
onPress()

onRelease()

Vector  position,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual]
 

Called when the component is context-clicked (usually using the right mouse button), called by the scrolling area with content-transformed coordinates.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event.
position The position where the context click occurred relative to the upper-left corner of the content.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.

virtual void onContentDoubleClick (  Component *  component,
Vector  position,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual]
 

Called when the component is double-clicked (usually using the left mouse button), called by the scrolling area with content-transformed coordinates.

A double click is raised when an onClick() event has been raised within a short time. onDoubleClick() is called after both onClick() method calls.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event.
position The position where the double click occurred relative to the upper-left corner of the content.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.
See also:
onClick()

virtual void onContentHold (  Component *  component,
Vector  position,
long  holdTime
)  [virtual]
 

Called when, after the event target is pressed down on the content (usually using the left mouse button), the pointer is not moved, but the button has not yet been released.

onContentHold() is called in the time between onContentPress() and onContentRelease(). Glaziery provides the time between the last call of onContentHold() and this one.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event.
position The current position of the pointer within the content, relative to the upper-left corner of the content.
holdTime The hold time between the last call of onContentHold() and this one, plus the hold time not consumed in the last call of onContentHold(). The time's unit is milli seconds.
See also:
onContentPress()

onContentRelease()

virtual void onContentPress (  Component *  component,
Vector  position,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual]
 

Called when the component is pressed down (usually using the left mouse button), called by the scrolling area with content-transformed coordinates.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event.
position The position where the click occurred relative to the upper-left corner of the content.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.
See also:
onRelease()

bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual]
 

Called when the event target press is released, called by the scrolling area with content-transformed coordinates.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.

virtual void onDestroying (  Component *  component  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the component is about to be destroyed (its memory is released).

This method is called before the component is deleted, but its parent container references may have been released already.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event.

Reimplemented in IntCycleEffect::ComponentDestroyListener, and Selector::PopupListener.

virtual void onDoubleClick (  EventTarget *  target,
Vector  position,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the target is double-clicked (usually using the left mouse button).

A double click is raised when an onClick() event has been raised within a short time. onDoubleClick() is called after both onClick() method calls.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
position The position where the double click occurred relative to the upper-left corner of the target.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.
See also:
onClick()

virtual void onDropped (  EventTarget *  draggedObject,
EventTarget *  dropTarget,
Vector  relativePosition,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when a dragging operation successfully ended.

This is when a dragging operation is in progress and the primary pointer button has been released.

Parameters:
draggedObject The event target that has been dragged.
dropTarget The event target where the object has been dropped.
relativePosition The relative position within the drop target.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.

virtual void onGotFocus (  Component *  component  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the component has just newly got the focus.

The component with focus e.g. receives the key events.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event.

virtual void onHotKey (  EventTarget *  target,
char  character,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when a hot key has been pressed on an event target.

Hot keys represent special characters e.g. to easily access fields (indicated by underlined characters).

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
character The hot key character pressed.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.

virtual void onHover (  EventTarget *  target  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the pointer is hovered over the event target for a while.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.

virtual void onKeyStroke (  EventTarget *  target,
int  keyCode,
bool  option1,
bool  option2
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when a planned key stroke has been pressed on the event target, the target has the inner-most focus, and the event not handled otherwise by the target.

Key strokes are usually received by key stroke fields. When the desktop is in key stroke mode, the next key pressed should be sent to this method. This is useful e.g. to define keyboard layouts for games.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
keyCode The key stroke key code.
option1 Whether the option button 1 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the SHIFT key.
option2 Whether the option button 2 is currently pressed, e.g. on Windows systems, this is the CTRL key.
See also:
Desktop::isKeyStrokeMode()

virtual void onLostFocus (  Component *  component  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the component has just lost the focus.

The component with focus e.g. receives the key events.

Parameters:
component The component that received the event, i.e. the component that lost the focus, not the now focused one. To see which component has the focus now, use Desktop::getFocusComponent().
See also:
Desktop::getFocusComponent()

onGotFocus()

)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the component has been moved.

Parameters:

oldSize The old size of the component before the resizing.

)  [virtual]

by pressing Ctrl+A on Windows systems), when the target has the inner-most focus, and the event not handled otherwise by the target.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.

virtual void onTab (  EventTarget *  target,
bool  secondary
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when the TAB key is pressed on the event target, the target has the inner-most focus, and the event not handled otherwise by the target.

Tabs step the focus from field to field.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
secondary Whether the secondary tabbing is used. E.g., on Windows systems, this is done by holding the control key.

int  delta
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Called when a pointer wheel (mouse, joystick, etc.) is changed while the mouse is over this event target.

Parameters:
target The target that received the event.
delta The relative wheel movement.

void release (   )  [inherited]
 

Decreases a reference count by one.

If no references remain, the object is automatically destroying itself.

void setModel (  void *  model,
void(*  modelDestructor)(void *model) = NULL
)  [inherited]
 

Sets the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Parameters:
model The application (or game) defined data.
modelDestructor An optional static method that is called, whenever the glaziery object is destroyed or when a new model is set. Specify this function only, if the model must be destroyed by this glaziery object, i.e. the object "owns" the model. If the model is a glaziery object itself, you may use the GlazieryObject::destructor() function.
See also:
destructor()

virtual void setSkinData (  SkinData *  skinData  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Sets the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Parameters:
skinData The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

Any previously set skin data is automatically destroyed.

Reimplemented in Component.

The string representation.
